Award.AwardTitle: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: Temperature-Dependent Phylogeography and Limits of Thermal Tolerance in Anolis carolinensis
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project aims to understand the physiological stresses that limit thermal tolerance in terrestrial ectothermic ("cold-blooded") animals (such as reptiles, amphibians and insects) and how those limitations affect a species' ability to survive changes climate. The hypothesis that extreme temperatures prevent all ectothermic species from effectively using oxygen has been widely applied to explain the limits of thermal tolerance. However, this hypothesis has been most heavily tested in aquatic species, raising the question: Does the same physiological stress effect air breathing species? Using the green anole lizard (Anolis carolinensis), the investigators seek to answer this question by combining physiological experimentation with genome sequencing to directly compare gene response under extreme temperatures to known genetic responses to hypoxia. Through this approach, the investigators seek to shed valuable light on the physiological mechanisms and evolutionary processes that allow terrestrial ectotherms to survive, function, and adapt to novel thermal niches.

In order to fully understand how climate change will affect biodiversity it is essential to integrate information about environmental change with data about species' ability to buffer, acclimate, and adapt to that change via physiological and genetic mechanisms. This project serves to accomplish this by combining information about thermal differences within the range of a species with the wealth of knowledge on the thermal biology of lizards and genomic resources only made available within the last few years. Combining these tools will allow for better predictions of how changes in climate will affect species' ranges and abundances around the world. This research will also result in the training of a graduate student and will provide research experiences for several undergraduates.

POR.DRECONTENT:
How do changes in the environment shape patterns of species formation, adaptation, and extinction? This is a central question of evolutionary biology. Temperature plays a key role in biological function. Changes in temperature extremes and variability can have ramifications at all levels of biological organization and consequently seed evolutionary change through natural selection. All organisms experience a range of temperatures over which they can maintain optimal performance. Thermal fluctuations outside this range can have consequences for individual’s survival, function, and reproduction. In a world of human-accelerated climate change this question has taken center stage as we seek to predict how changes in climate will influence ecosystems around the globe and prepare conservations efforts to minimize their impact.

This project investigated several important questions regard the evolution of thermal tolerance in new environments using the green anole lizard, Anolis carolinensis as a model. The green anole occupies diverse thermal environments from subtropical Florida and southern Texas to temperate climates along the foothills of the Smoky Mountains, where cold winters provide extreme pressure for survival. The closest relatives of this species are isolated to warm, thermally stable environments in Cuba. Therefore, the migration of the species out of its ancestral range into novel thermal habitats provides a natural experiment for understanding how “cold-blooded” organisms adapt to novel climate.

We asked what physiologically set the limits of thermal tolerance in reptiles and how do animals modify their physiology to change their thermal limits in the face of new thermal environments? We test the hypothesis that extreme temperatures affect mechanisms involved in oxygen transport and utilization, leading to loss of function as oxygen supply and utilization fail to meet biological needs and animals become dependent on anaerobic metabolism for energy. We found that lizards with greater cold tolerance are less dependent on anaerobic metabolism and colder temperatures, supporting our hypothesis of oxygen limitation. Animals with greater cold tolerance also show lower levels of oxygen utilization at low temperatures. This suggests that aerobic metabolism is more efficient in lizards with greater cold tolerance, allowing for greater conservation of energy in cold environments. Furthermore, we found significant effects of acclimation treatment and population-of-origin on these patterns: lizards placed under cold conditions display adaptive plasticity of cold tolerance and metabolism and lizards from populations that have evolved in colder environments display greater cold tolerance and greater levels of energy conservation than those from warmer environments regardless of temperature treatment. We are currently analyzing liver transcriptomes from this experiment to gain a better understanding of the genes involved in thermal acclimation and adaptation of lizards to colder environments.

Global climate change is expected to increase the frequency and magnitude of extreme weather events across the globe. Studies such as this provide important information about how species can respond to these events. As evolutionary biologists continue to gather this type of data, the findings may be important for pinpointing populations that are resilient or vulnerable to predicted changes in climate and inform conservation efforts that will be key in preserving the world’s biodiversity. This project formed a core component of the lead investigator’s dissertation work, for which he has received a doctorate in evolutionary biology.  Several undergraduate students from Harvard University and University of Illinois, Champaign-Urbana were trained in physiological experimentation during the course of this research.
